Sure, here is an updated grammar system for Flang that includes definite and indefinite articles:

Nouns:
- Accusative case: nouns are inflected by adding the ending "-a" in the accusative case. For example, "fash" (house) becomes "fasha" in the accusative case.
- Genitive case: nouns are inflected by adding the ending "-i" in the genitive case. For example, "fash" (house) becomes "fashi" in the genitive case.
- Instrumental case: nouns are inflected by adding the ending "-u" in the instrumental case. For example, "fash" (house) becomes "fashu" in the instrumental case.

Verbs:
- Accusative case: verbs are inflected by adding the ending "-a" in the accusative case. For example, "fala" (to walk) becomes "falaa" in the accusative case.
- Genitive case: verbs are inflected by adding the ending "-i" in the genitive case. For example, "fala" (to walk) becomes "falai" in the genitive case.
- Instrumental case: verbs are inflected by adding the ending "-u" in the instrumental case. For example, "fala" (to walk) becomes "falau" in the instrumental case.

Articles:
- Definite article: the definite article in Flang is "fi" and it is added before the noun. For example, "fash" (house) becomes "fi fash" when it is modified by the definite article.
- Indefinite article: the indefinite article in Flang is "fa" and it is added before the noun. For example, "fash" (house) becomes "fa fash" when it is modified by the indefinite article.
